security: This dispatch reveals CIA interest in and monitoring of the Beheiren, a Japanese anti-war group, and its activities related to U.S. Navy deserters.  Disclosing the group's connections to Soviet officials and U.S. pacifists, as well as operational details such as safe houses and communication methods, could expose intelligence sources and methods. Specifically, the document mentions a covert phone tap on the Soviet Embassy’s line. Sharing these details could compromise ongoing intelligence operations.
summary: A CIA dispatch from Tokyo details the activities of BEHEIREN, a Japanese anti-Vietnam War committee, particularly its role in assisting four U.S. Navy deserters to defect to the USSR. It outlines BEHEIREN's organization, key figures, Soviet connections, and impact on Japanese public opinion.
summary_one_paragraph: This dispatch from the Chief of Station in Tokyo to the CIA's Sov Bloc and Far East Divisions reports on the BEHEIREN, a Japanese anti-Vietnam War group, with a focus on its assistance to four U.S. Navy deserters. The report details BEHEIREN's origins as a group of ex-JCP members and leftist intellectuals led by YOSHIKAWA Yuichi and fronted by ODA Makoto, its organizational structure, and its success in exploiting the deserters' case for propaganda. It notes BEHEIREN's connections to Soviet officials, U.S. pacifists, and its ability to mobilize public sympathy, further including lists of identified BEHEIREN supporters, activities, and foreign contacts, as well as press clippings and related intelligence reports.
title: RYBAT MIPASHA REDTOP - Beheiren and the Four U.S. Navy Deserters
recipient: Chief, Sov Bloc Div; Chief, Far East Division
